ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about many of the most influential movements and thinkers in terms of political philosophy from the Renaissance until the 20th century, while also developing my ability to critically discuss and write about ideas of political theory and historical progress.

Thematic ideas of historical and political thought, and how those ideas have progressed and developed over time. Being able to analyze, articulate, and write about historical ideas and themes and connect them through one another.
Analysis of political philosophy, writing skills
I learned how to craft more nuanced arguments and engage with important texts.
Knowledge of political philosophy, how to clearly write an argumentative paper

better writing skills, especially in terms of doing comparative writing and analyzing a range of texts. making connections between different political philosophers and historians we had read the first semester in H&P as well as with philosophers we were currently reading in philosophy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the syllabus of the course was varied and well-designed in terms of giving us a sense of historical movement and eras, and I really enjoyed the high level of class discussion during the seminars. I will say in general that I wish a bit more historical context had been given for the texts that we read, and that conversations in class had been a bit more grounded in that.

The breadth of the course is enormous: there is a lot of influential thinkers and ideas that are discussed, who all had enormous impacts on political thought. Being able to do this is pretty cool. However, this obviously sacrifices depth. There is only so much time, and you can feel as though you are missing essential points from some authors and in some texts -- because you are and you have to with the time permitted.
I appreciated the engagement online through posting discussion questions and I also felt like our class discussions were very strong and illuminating.

The strengths of this course lie in the material  all of the texts are extremely interesting and it is easy to make connections between each text and the texts from first semester. In terms of weaknesses, I think we often rushed through the books when we could have spent more time on fewer texts.

Strengths: There was a clear theme amongst the works this semester so it made it easier to understand/make connections between the works. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes it felt as if the conversation would be stalled or the flow would make it difficult to continue.

I thought the readings were very well-chosen and seemed to connect with each other (e.g. reading Hobbes, Rousseau, and Locke one after the other worked very neatly). I think there could have been more clarity on what to expect from H&P essays generally. I found this to be an issue both semesters as I think both philosophy and literature have very defined expectations and styles of papers but I was a little confused about how to read and write about H&P texts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the seminar format was very effective in terms of virtual learning, but the prerecorded lectures were challenging in terms of attention span and retention.
I think it would be better if there could have been some form of live lecture, as opposed to exclusively recorded ones.

I'm not sure that posting discussion questions was the best way to engage virtually, at least for me. I feel like it didn't require much effort or thought but it was simply an extra task that I had to remember to check off and complete before class. Perhaps taking turns leading or presenting for one class each week (we did this in my DS philosophy class) might be a better option. I think even posting a paragraph or some thoughts after class and encouraging students to comment on each other's thoughts via discussion (although it might be more work) would be a lot more thought-provoking and effective.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend it to someone that wants to gain a basic understanding of the texts on the syllabus and to be able to discuss their ideas intelligently with other people, because I feel like the knowledge learned through this course is truly crucial in terms of political conversations in the modern day.

I would highly recommend this course if they are clearly interested in the Directed Studies program or the broad thematic ideas. I also would just recommend it to anyone: I think everyone has potential to grow and benefit as a result from this course, and this course can really think about everything. This course challenges you: it challenges preconceived beliefs and ideas you may have and takes you in a new direction. Each thinker is different and maybe contradictory, so in attempting to reconcile them with each other, and yourself, you have to really dive into what you believe, what they believe, and how those thoughts can actually interact with each other.
I would recommend DS in general to any student who would like a general overview of the authors on the syllabus.  I had very little experience with these authors and found the course very accessible.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in modern political philosophy.
If they were interested in political philosophy/DS, then sure.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures
recorded lecture and twice weekly seminar
Recorded Lecture and live seminar.
recorded lectures
